facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 234 of 1959 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 234 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal from the order dated February 15, 1957 of the Bombay High Court of Judicature at Nagpur in Special Civil Application No. 2-N of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the order dated February 15, 1957 of the Bombay High Court of Judicature at Nagpur in Special Civil Application No. 2-N of 1956.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on March 28, 1961 by KAPUR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 28. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-This is an appeal on a certificate by the High Court of Bombay against the judgment and order of that Court passed on a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution by the present appellants in regard to the legality of the numberification levying an octroi duty on certain goods.

facts.text: Appellants are some of the ratepayers of the Municipal Committee of Shegaon which is respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are some of the ratepayers of the Municipal Committee of Shegaon which is respondent No. I in this appeal.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 is the State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The other respondent is the State of Bombay.

facts.text: Appellants were carrying on trade and business which involved bringing goods within the limits of the Municipal Committee.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were carrying on trade and business which involved their bringing goods within the limits of the Municipal Committee.

facts.text: On July 25, 1954, the Municipal Committee passed a resolution for levying an octroi duty instead of terminal tax.

anchor.surface_text: On July 25,1954, the Municipal Committee passed a resolution for tile purpose of levying an octroi duty instead of terminal tax.

facts.text: Resolution was published in the State Gazette on June 29, 1956, along with rules for assessment.

anchor.surface_text: This resolution was published in the State Gazette on June 29, 1956, along with rules for assessment.

facts.text: On August 4, 1956, objections were invited to the proposed tax.

anchor.surface_text: Oil August 4, 1956, objections were invited to the proposed tax.

facts.text: Objections by the first appellant were filed on August 4, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The objections by the first appellant were filed on August 4, 1956, and by some others on August 5 and 6.

facts.text: Objections by some others filed on August 5 and 6, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: and by some others on August 5 and 6.

facts.text: At a meeting of the Municipal Committee on August 16, 1956, objections of other appellants were rejected as time barred.

anchor.surface_text: At a meeting of the Municipal Committee dated August 16, 1956, the objections of the other appellants were rejected as being time barred and those by the first appellant were rejected because it was the only objector whose objections were within time.

facts.text: Objections by first appellant rejected because it was the only objector within time.

anchor.surface_text: those by the first appellant were rejected because it was the only objector whose objections were within time.

facts.text: Some representations made by first appellant to the Government.

anchor.surface_text: Some representations were made by the first appellant to the Government and a few days later the other objectors also made similar representations

facts.text: Government issued notification sanctioning imposition of the tax and Draft Rules on October 27, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: but the Government issued the numberification sanctioning the imposition of the tax and the Draft Rules on October 27, 1956, though the Gazette Notifications were published on two separate dates, i.e., October 30 and October 31, 1956.

facts.text: Gazette Notifications published on October 30 and October 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: though the Gazette Notifications were published on two separate dates, i.e., October 30 and October 31, 1956.

facts.text: Appellants filed petition under Art. 226 in High Court of Bombay at Nagpur challenging legality of imposition of tax.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then filed a petition under Art. 226 in the High Court of Bombay at Nagpur challenging the legality of the, imposition of the tax.

facts.text: Two main grounds urged: 1. notification ultra vires because s.67 not complied with; 2. rate of tax on certain articles more than maximum.

anchor.surface_text: Two main grounds were urged-  1  that the numberification was ultra vires because s. 67 of the C. P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922  Act II of 1922 , hereinafter termed the Act, had number been companyplied with and  2  that the rate of tax in regard to certain articles was unauthorised in that it was more than the maximum which companyld be levied under the law.

facts.text: High Court rejected first ground but accepted second and gave relief.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the first ground but accepted the second objection and gave relief accordingly.

facts.text: Appellants Nos. 2 to 6 have not taken steps for prosecution of appeal; appeal dismissed for non-prosecution for them.

anchor.surface_text: Appellants Nos. 2 to 6 have number taken steps for the prosecution of the appeal and the appeal, in so far as it relates to them, is dismissed for number-prosecution.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 challenges vires on grounds: 1. not all steps under s.67 taken; 2. no notification imposing octroi duty.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant No. 1 before us has challenged the vires of the imposition on two grounds  1  that all the steps necessary for the imposition of the octroi duty had number been taken and therefore s. 67 had number been companyplied with and  2  that as a matter of fact there was numbernotification imposing an octroi duty.

facts.text: Objections of appellant No. 1 within time but not considered on merits, rejected merely because only one objector.

anchor.surface_text: The objection to the vires of the numberification in regard to procedure is that the objections raised by appellant No. 1, though within time, werenot companysidered on their merits and were rejected merely on the ground that there was only one objector

facts.text: High Court found non-consideration of objections was error in procedure but rejected plea due to s.67(8).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected this plea because of s. 67 8 , although it found that number-consideration of the objections was an error in procedure.

facts.text: Two notifications issued by Government on October 27, 1956; published October 30 and 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: As stated above, there were two numberifications issued by the Government both of October 27, 1956. One was published in the Gazette on October 30, 1956, and the other on the following day.

facts.text: First notification No. 4963-5869-M-XIII sanctions draft rules for assessment, collection and refund of octroi tax under ss.71,76,85.

anchor.surface_text: The first numberification was as follows- No. 4963-5869-M-XIII.-In exercise of the pow- ers companyferred by sections 71, 76 and 85 of the Central Provinces and Berar Municipalities Act, 1922  11 of 1922 , the State Government are pleased to sanction the following draft rules for assessment, companylection and refund of the octroi tax within the limits of the Shegaon Municipality, in the Buldana District.

facts.text: Second notification No. 4962-5869-M-XIII confirms draft rules for imposition of octroi tax under s.67(2) [mistake, should be 67(7)].

anchor.surface_text: And the second numberification stated- No. 4962-5869-M-XIII.-In exercise of the pow- ers companyferred by sub-section  2  of section 67 of the Central Provinces and Berar Municipalities Act, 1922  II of 1922 , the State Government are pleased to companyfirm the following draft rules for the imposition of the octroi tax within the limits of the SHEGAON MUNICIPAL COMMITTEE, in the Buldana district, under clause  c  of sub- s.  1  of section 66 of the said Act, on animals and goods brought for sale, expenditure or use in supersession of the rules of terminal tax, sanctioned under Notification No. 3716-B-VIII dated the 15th February, 1921.

facts.text: Second notification directs imposition of octroi and is conclusive evidence under s.67(7).

anchor.surface_text: This numberification therefore clearly is one which directs imposition of octroi and falls within sub- s.  7  of s. 67 and having been numberified in the Gazette it is companyclusive evidence of the tax having been imposed in accordance with the provisions of the Act
passed on a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution by the present appellants in regard to the legality of the numberification levying an octroi duty on certain goods.

arguments.claim: The second notification citing sub-s.(2) of s.67 is a mistake and should have been under sub-s.(7); it directs imposition of octroi

anchor.surface_text: The second notification on the face of it is under sub-s. (2) of s. 67. It appears to us that this is a mistake and should have been under sub-s. (7) of s. 67.

arguments.claim: The second notification confirms draft rules for imposition of octroi tax under clause (c) of s.66(1) and directs imposition, falling within s.67(7); notified in Gazette, it is conclusive evidence of compliance

anchor.surface_text: The first notification was as follows- No. 4963-5869-M-XIII.-In exercise of the powers conferred by sections 71, 76 and 85 of the Central Provinces and Berar Municipalities Act, 1922 (II of 1922)

holdings.text: The appeal, in so far as it relates to Appellants Nos. 2 to 6, is dismissed for non-prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: Appellants Nos. 2 to 6 have number taken steps for the prosecution of the appeal and the appeal, in so far as it relates to them, is dismissed for number-prosecution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants Nos. 2 to 6 failed to take steps for prosecution of the appeal.

holdings.text: The second notification, though citing sub-section (2) of section 67, is actually under sub-section (7) of section 67 as it confirms draft rules for the imposition of the octroi tax.

anchor.surface_text: And the second numberification stated- No. 4962-5869-M-XIII.-In exercise of the pow- ers companyferred by sub-section  2  of section 67 of the Central Provinces and Berar Municipalities Act, 1922  II of 1922 , the State Government are pleased to companyfirm the following draft rules for the imposition of the octroi tax within the limits of the SHEGAON MUNICIPAL COMMITTEE, in the Buldana district, under clause  c  of sub- s.  1  of section 66 of the said Act, on animals and goods brought for sale, expenditure or use in supersession of the rules of terminal tax, sanctioned under Notification No. 3716-B-VIII dated the 15th February, 1921.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Face cites sub-s.(2) but content confirms rules for imposition including levy on commodities at rates; mistake in subsection reference.

holdings.text: The second notification directs imposition of octroi and falls within sub-section (7) of section 67; having been notified in the Gazette, it is conclusive evidence of the tax having been imposed in accordance with the provisions of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: This numberification therefore clearly is one which directs imposition of octroi and falls within sub- s.  7  of s. 67 and having been numberified in the Gazette it is companyclusive evidence of the tax having been imposed in accordance with the provisions of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification confirms and directs imposition via rules specifying levy, classes, rates; Gazette publication triggers conclusive evidence under s.67(7).

holdings.text: The imposition of the tax cannot be challenged on the ground that all the necessary steps had not been taken.

anchor.surface_text: and it cannot be challenged on the ground that all the necessary steps had number been taken.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conclusive evidence provision in s.67(7) precludes inquiry into procedural compliance including consideration of objections.

holdings.text: The issuance of the notification imposing a tax shall be conclusive evidence that the tax had been imposed in accordance with the provisions of the Act, supporting rejection of plea despite procedural error in objection consideration.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected this plea because of s. 67 8 , although it found that number-consideration of the objections was an error in procedure. The language of sub- s.  8  lends support to this view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language of s.67(7)/(8) provides conclusive evidence curing procedural irregularities like non-merits consideration of timely objections.

The fact of publishing a resolution along with rules for assessment satisfies the powers under Section 71 of the C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, for making rules on assessment, as indicated by matching descriptions of rules for assessment.
The fact describes the publication of the resolution in the State Gazette, which pertains to the second notification central to the issue of its classification under section 67 subsections.
